facts.text: Appellant Ramesh Amin and seven others tried in Court of Session, Aurangabad, for offences under ss. 366, 366A IPC and abetment thereof. Appellant was third accused.
Sessions Judge convicted accused Nos. 1 to 4 and 7, sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for two years for each offence, acquitted the rest.

Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1207 of 1960 dated December 20, 1960, acquitted accused Nos. 1 to 4 and 7 of offences under s. 366 r/w s. 34 and s. 366A IPC, but convicted appellant of abetting seventh accused Patilba under s. 366A r/w s. 109 IPC.
Seventh accused Patilba resident of Aurangabad, eighth accused his wife.

Anusaya daughter of Shakuntala by husband Kashinath. After Kashinath's death, Shakuntala brought infant Anusaya to Patilba's house and lived as his mistress. Later Shakuntala left for Nasik, Anusaya continued living with Patilba and was brought up by him.
Patilba arranged marriage of Anusaya with Ramlal, but Anusaya declined to live with husband.
Patilba introduced Anusaya to customers, she started indulging in promiscuous intercourse for money.
On January 13, 1960, appellant went to Patilba's residence and asked him to bring Anusaya and Chandrakala (prostitute) to Gulzar Theatre.
Patilba, eighth accused, Chandrakala and Anusaya went to Gulzar Theatre. At instance of appellant, Anusaya and Chandrakala taken by Devidas (approver) to Bohori Kathada.

Sub-Inspector Pagare raided Bohori Kathada on information of illicit liquor consumption. Found accused Nos. 1 to 5 and Devidas consuming liquor, Chandrakala and Anusaya in inner apartment. Arrested them.
Medical examination showed Anusaya had not attained age of 18 years.
Pagare filed information for Bombay Prohibition Act offences (accused acquitted) and ss. 366, 366A IPC against nine persons including appellant, Patilba, Devidas.
During commitment proceedings, Devidas tendered pardon as approver.

Anusaya at material time had not attained 18 years, brought up by Patilba, married but living under his guardianship, accustomed to promiscuous intercourse for money, entertained 1-2 customers daily, habituated to prostitution.
On day in question, Anusaya and Chandrakala went to Gulzar Theatre with Patilba seeking customers, went to entrance during break but returned due to police van.
Anusaya and Chandrakala went to Bohori Kathada to carry on profession as prostitutes.
No evidence Anusaya unwilling to go to Gulzar Theatre or Bohori Kathada.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant can be held guilty of abetting the commission of an offence punishable under s. 366A IPC by Patilba by instigating him to bring Anusaya to the theatre and then to Bohori Kathada.

Ingredients of offence under s. 366A IPC: (a) minor girl below 18 induced by accused, (b) induced to go from any place or do any act, (c) with intent or knowledge she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant cannot in law be held guilty of abetting offence under s. 366A IPC by Patilba.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in convicting appellant of abetment under s. 366A r/w s. 109 IPC as there is no evidence Patilba induced Anusaya; she was willing and accustomed to prostitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Merely accompanying a prostitute (even minor) to ply her trade does not constitute inducement under s. 366A.

court_reasoning.text: Anusaya was habituated to prostitution, offered herself for money promiscuously; no reluctance to overcome, hence no 'seduction' or 'forcing' as contemplated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Seduction implies overcoming reluctance; professional prostitute has no such scruples.

court_reasoning.text: s. 366A enacted to implement International Convention; but facts do not make out procuration of minor girl.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No intent or knowledge of forcing/seducing where girl is professional prostitute.

holdings.text: Person who merely accompanies a woman going out to ply her profession of prostitute, even if below 18, does not commit offence under s. 366A IPC; no inducement with intent/knowledge of forcing/seducing.
Seduction in ss. 366/366A used in wider sense, not limited to first illicit intercourse; but does not apply to professional prostitutes offering services promiscuously for money.

key_quotes.text: a person who merely accompanies a woman going out to ply her profession of a prostitute, even if she has not attained the age of eighteen years, does not thereby commit an offence under s. 366A of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no offence without inducement to overcome reluctance

key_quotes.text: Seduction implies surrender of her body by a woman who is otherwise reluctant or unwilling to submit herself to illicit intercourse in consequence of persuasion, flattery, blandishment or importunity
